docs.snippet: A contract for a new type of marine propulsion plant known as a free-piston gas generator-turbine, which is to be installed in one of four Liberty ships slated for conversion, was awarded yesterday to the General Motors Corporation, Cleveland Diesel...
docs.lead_paragraph: A contract for a new type of marine propulsion plant known as a free-piston gas generator-turbine, which is to be installed in one of four Liberty ships slated for conversion, was awarded yesterday to the General Motors Corporation, Cleveland Diesel Engine Division.
docs.abstract: GM Cleveland Diesel Engine Div gets Maritime Adm contract for free-piston gas generator-turbine for Liberty ship as part of experimental conversion program; Adm asks bids for converting another Liberty to Diesel power

headline.main: ITEMS OF INTEREST IN SHIPPING FIELD; General Motors to Build New Propulsion Plant -- Fete Is Held Aboard the Managua

docs.snippet: British sterling was definitely on the offered side last week chiefly at the instance of lower markets in London where there persisted the accumulation of American dollars for grain and other seasonal commitments.

headline.main: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES; Week Ended Sept. 17, 1954

docs.snippet: The first decline in Latin-American draft indebtedness in five months was recorded in August, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly survey of the draft experience of fifteen commercial banks.
docs.lead_paragraph: The first decline in Latin-American draft indebtedness in five months was recorded in August, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly survey of the draft experience of fifteen commercial banks.
docs.abstract: NY Fed Reserve Bank repts 1st drop in draft debt in 5 mos, Aug; payments up $1.8 million

docs.snippet: A slump in British sterling last week dropped it to $2.79 3/8, lowest since October, 1952. It was a continuation of an easier tendency begun in the last week of August. The week's highest was $2.80 1/8 (Monday) and the close on Friday, $2.79 3/8, a...
docs.lead_paragraph: A slump in British sterling last week dropped it to $2.79 3/8, lowest since October, 1952. It was a continuation of an easier tendency begun in the last week of August. The week's highest was $2.80 1/8 (Monday) and the close on Friday, $2.79 3/8, a loss of 11/16 cent from the preceding week. Business was in good volume, although not nearly as heavy as the size of the decline might indicate.
